Reproduced on Nexus 6P (real device) and Google Pixel 3 XL with Android 10.0 (emulator).
 
**Describe the Bug:**

A clear description of what is the bug is.

**To Reproduce:**
1. Create a bottom sheet material dialog with WRAP_CONTENT in a DialogFragment.
2. Add a custom adapter that has item views with checkboxes.
3. Show the dialog.
4. Check/uncheck a checkbox for an item.
5. Switch to a different app.
6. Switch back to your app.
7. Dialog title and content are gone and only the dialog's transparent background remains. If you set positive/negative buttons, they are still showing.
8. Switch to different app.
9. Switch back to your app.
10. Title and content are back...
11. Switch to/from different app, title and content stays.
12. Check a different item.
13. Switch to/from different app, title and content are gone.

**Expected Behavior:**

Should show your dialog with content every time it resumes, exactly as it was.

**Notes:**

1. Has nothing to do with app being killed from memory pressure.
2. Only happens for WRAP_CONTENT bottom sheets. The same code works fine for MATCH_PARENT bottom sheets or non-bottom sheet dialogs.
3. Caller is a Fragment (I'm using android navigation component).
4. If you don't touch any checkboxes in the item view, and you pause/resume your app, it works as expected. It's only when you check/uncheck the checkboxes.
5. Positive/negative buttons are unaffected: they show no matter what.

My guess is it's setting the height to 0 for some reason?

            .show {

}

**Describe the Bug:**
When using `DatePicker` with max and min date defined as `Calendar`, and dates set to the same day, application crashes with following error:
```
java.lang.IllegalStateException: Min date must be less than max date.
	at com.afollestad.date.controllers.MinMaxController.validateMinAndMax(MinMaxController.kt:121)
```
Checking the timestamps (`Calendar` class field named `time`) , I've provided given values:
```
minDate - 1586131200000
currentDate - 1586174400000
maxDate - 1586217599999
```
Timestamps indicate, that minDate is in fact less then maxDate, yet the error still occurs. This only happens with maxDate set - min and current date behave correctly, even when set to the same day. Looking into `DatePickerExt.kt` I've found that only two date checks are present:
```kotlin
  check(minDate == null || currentDate == null || minDate.before(currentDate)) {
    "Your `minDate` must be less than `currentDate`."
  }
  check(maxDate == null || currentDate == null || maxDate.after(currentDate)) {
    "Your `maxDate` must be bigger than `currentDate`."
  }
```
There is no check for maxDate that causes this error.

**To Reproduce:**
1. Generate three Calendar objects at the same day, with different time set
2. Use generated dates in `datePicker()` method to define min, max, and current date
3. Show created dialog

**Expected Behavior:**
Library shows a DatePicker dialog, where user is only allowed to select current date. Rest of the days is grayed out. This happens, when minDate is set to the same day as currentDate, and I would expect maxDate to behave the same way.
